key_title: Key to the genera of Euphorbiaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Euphorbiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Euphorbiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves with margins lobed and/or coarsely toothed
Leaves with margins entire to shallowly toothed, or leaves scale-like
Leaves usually less than 8 cm wide, never palmately divided; fruit less than 15 mm long
Leaves 10–30 cm wide, palmately divided into 7–9 serrate lobes; fruit a spiny capsule 15–25 mm long
[link through]
At least some flowers with a perianth (sometimes very small); involucre of bracts absent; milky latex absent

Flowers all lacking individual perianths; inflorescence consisting of 1 female flower and 8–10 male flowers, surrounded by a calyx-like involucre of bracts; plant exuding a milky latex if cut or broken
Stems not leafless at flowering time; plant not broom-like
Stems leafless or nearly so at flowering time; plant broom-like
Plants with stellate hairs at least on young shoots
Plants glabrous or with simple hairs only
Plant herbaceous; leaves broad-ovate to rhombic, petiole as long as lamina
Plant a shrub, small tree or herb; leaves not as above, petiole much shorter than lamina
Plant sparsely covered with stellate hairs; leaves entire or toothed; styles 3, bifid; capsule covered with peltate scales
Plant densely covered with stellate hairs; leaves entire; style 1, simple; capsule smooth
[link through]
[link through]
Flowers solitary or in small clusters in axils; perianth usually in 1 whorl
Flowers terminal; sepals and petals usually present in all flowers
Stamens cohering in a central column; styles 3, almost free, deeply bifid; capsule ovoid or oblong, usually 1-seeded
Stamens free; stigma sessile, entire or more or less 3-lobed; capsule subglobose, 3-seeded
[link through]
Tender annuals; leaves opposite
Woody perennials; leaves all or mostly alternate
[link through]
Leaves broadly ovate, almost as wide as long, often reddish; flowers numerous, in slender, terminal, spike-like racemes; perianth inconspicuous
Leaves distinctly longer than wide; flowers solitary or clustered in axils, or if ever terminal, then perianth conspicuous
[link through]
Flowers solitary in axils; perianth usually in 1 whorl
Flowers terminal; sepals and petals usually present in all flowers
Stamens cohering in a central column; styles 3, almost free, deeply bifid; capsule ovoid or oblong, usually 1-seeded
Stamens free; stigma sessile, entire or more or less 3-lobed; capsule subglobose, 3-seeded
